questions.text:
A 19-year-old man comes to the emergency department with fever, chills, sore throat, and abdominal pain for the past 3 days. He is a college student living on campus, and reports that many other students in his dorm are sick as well. His medical history is non-contributory. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg. Physical examination shows enlarged posterior lymph nodes on the neck and oropharyngeal examination shows bilateral tonsillar erythema with exudates. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. Rapid strep test is negative, and direct Coombs test is positive. Peripheral blood smear is shown below:  


 Reproduced from: Wikipedia 

Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with fever, sore throat, splenomegaly, posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and a negative rapid Strep test has infectious mononucleosis. The positive direct Coombs test and CD8+ reactive T-lymphocytes on peripheral blood smear indicate cold (IgM-mediated) autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). This occurs as a result of the production of cold agglutinins, which are autoantibodies that target erythrocyte membranes and mark them for destruction in the spleen.  

Hemolytic anemias can be classified based on the location of erythrocyte destruction (i.e., intravascular or extravascular), as well the etiology of the hemolysis (i.e., intrinsic vs. extrinsic). Extravascular hemolysis is defined by erythrocyte destruction outside of blood vessels, typically in the reticuloendothelial system (i.e. macrophages in the spleen), and intravascular hemolysis is defined by erythrocyte destruction within blood vessels. Extrinsic anemia is defined as hemolysis resulting from a problem outside of the erythrocyte and is typically acquired (e.g., autoimmune, infections, microangiopathic), whereas intrinsic anemia is defined as hemolysis resulting from a problem with the erythrocyte itself and is typically caused by enzyme deficiencies, commonly seen in congenital conditions (e.g., sickle cell disease, G6PD, hereditary spherocytosis).  

The type of hemolysis present can be determined based on laboratory findings. In intravascular hemolysis, hemoglobin released inside blood vessels is bound by haptoglobin and both molecules are removed together. Therefore, haptoglobin levels decrease sharply. When haptoglobin levels are depleted, hemoglobin is excreted through the kidneys, resulting in hemoglobinuria and hemosiderinuria. Hemoglobinuria and hemosiderinuria can cause kidney damage, and patients may present with back pain.    

In extravascular hemolysis, erythrocytes are destroyed outside of blood vessels, so haptoglobin levels are normal and there is no hemoglobin or hemosiderin in the urine. Erythrocyte destruction occurs in the spleen and liver, so patients may present with hepatosplenomegaly.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hemosiderinuria:
Incorrect: Hemosiderinuria is associated with intravascular hemolysis. Common causes include paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and macroangiopathic hemolytic anemias.  
✅ Normal haptoglobin levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC):
Incorrect: Increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) is associated with hereditary spherocytosis.  
❌ Pancytopenia:
Incorrect: Pancytopenia is associated with aplastic anemia, which is characterized by bone marrow and subsequent myeloid hematopoietic stem cell destruction. Common causes include radiation, certain drugs (benzene, chloramphenicol, alkylating agents, antimetabolites), viral infections (EBV, HIV, hepatitis), and Fanconi anemia.   
❌ Thrombocytopenia:
Incorrect: Thrombocytopenia is associated with a type of intravascular hemolytic anemia called microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA).

questions.text: A 29-year-old Chinese primigravid woman comes to the clinic at 24 weeks gestation for the first time due to decreased fetal movements. Her prenatal care has been inconsistent, but she has been taking vitamins daily. The patient’s past medical history is significant for anemia. An ultrasound is performed and shows increased placental thickness. The ultrasound also reveals fetal ascites as well as pericardial and pleural effusions. The amniotic fluid index is measured to be 26 cm. Which of the following most accurately describes the predominant form of hemoglobin found in this fetus?
questions.solution:
The ultrasound findings in this case show a massive accumulation of fluid in serous cavities (e.g., ascites, pleural and pericardial effusions), which is characteristic of hydrops fetalis. This fetus likely has hemoglobin Barts disease due to deletion of all 4 alpha-globin genes, resulting in anemia and subsequent high-output cardiac failure causing massive total body edema.  

Hemoglobin Barts occurs when alpha-globin chains are not synthesized, resulting in 4 gamma-globin chains which cluster and form a tetramer. This form of hemoglobin has an extremely high affinity for oxygen, causing widespread tissue hypoxia. The resulting fetal anemia leads to a hemodynamic compensatory process that involves increasing intravascular volume to provide enough tissue perfusion, ultimately leading to the hydrops features commonly seen in these fetuses.    

Hemoglobin Barts disease is incompatible with life, with most cases resulting in fetal death usually in the second through third trimester of pregnancy or within a few hours after birth.  

Hemoblogin Barts disease is more common in individuals of Asian descent, since the cis-deletion of the alpha-globin genes is more prevalent in this population. In this vignette, the mother’s previous history of anemia and Asian descent likely means she is a carrier of the cis-deletion. In order for the fetus to have hemoglobin Barts disease, the child’s father must have had a similar cis-deletion.  



Option Analysis

✅ γγγγ:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ ααββ:
Incorrect:  HbA1 is the predominant form of hemoglobin present in adults, and consists of 2α-globin subunits and 2β-globin subunits. The fetus in this case likely has a severe form of alpha thalassemia, wherein α-globin subunits cannot be synthesized. Hence, it is unlikely this fetus has predominantly HbA1 hemoglobin.
❌ ααγγ:
Incorrect: Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) is a hemoglobin variant made of 2α-globin subunits and 2γ-globin subunits. In healthy fetuses, HbF is the predominant type of hemoglobin since it has a higher affinity for oxygen than adult hemoglobin. The fetus in this case likely has a severe form of alpha thalassemia wherein α-globin subunits cannot be synthesized, therefore making this form of hemoglobin unlikely in the fetus. 
❌ ααδδ:
Incorrect: HbA2 is a minor form of hemoglobin (makes up less than 3% of total hemoglobin) present in adults, and consists of 2α-globin subunits and 2δ-globin subunits. Increased levels of HbA2 can be seen in patients with beta-thalassemia, since these patients have a reduced ability to form HbA1 (ααββ) which requires β-globin subunits. The ultrasound of the fetus demonstrates a severe form of alpha-thalassemia wherein α-globin subunits cannot be synthesized. Hence, it is unlikely this fetus has predominantly HbA2 hemoglobin.
❌ ααβSβS:
Incorrect: Sickle cell disease is caused by a mutation in the β-globin subunit of hemoglobin, resulting in dysfunctional hemoglobin that distorts into a sickle shape. The abnormal hemoglobin can occlude vessels and cause ischemia. Sickle cell disease typically presents early in childhood and would not present with massive effusions and ascites in a fetus.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old female comes to the clinic for a follow-up visit. She visited several weeks ago for a routine visit, and a complete blood count (CBC) showed mild anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 11.2 g/dL. The physician prescribed her daily oral iron supplementation, and she has been taking it as prescribed. The patient’s menstrual periods have been regular with normal flow. She immigrated from Greece 15 years ago and has had no significant past medical history. Laboratory results obtained at the current visit are shown below:  
 
 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  11.3 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume  71 fL 

Which of the following sets of additional laboratory findings are most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This adult female, who has mild anemia refractory to iron supplementation, likely has B-thalassemia minor. B-thalassemia minor is caused by a mutation of only 1 of the 2 B-globin genes. Patients with the condition usually present with mild microcytic, hypochromic anemia and are asymptomatic. Most patients are unaware that they are carriers; oftentimes, the mild microcytic anemia is incorrectly attributed to iron deficiency, but iron supplements do not benefit these patients since they have sufficient levels of iron.  

Normal adult hemoglobin (hemoglobin A1) consists of 2 alpha chains and 2 beta chains (ααββ) along with heme. Beta-thalassemias, both minor and major, are caused by faulty B-globin chain synthesis due to point mutations in promoter sequences or splice sites, affecting transcription, mRNA processing, and translation, ultimately resulting in decreased B-globin chain synthesis. In patients with B-thalassemia minor, the mildly reduced synthesis of B-globin chains results in increased production of hemoglobin that does not involve incorporation of B-globin, such as hemoglobin A2 (HbA2) and fetal hemoglobin (HbF). Therefore, there is an increased production of HbA2, which consists of 2 alpha chains and 2 delta chains (ααδδ), and occasionally HbF, which consists of 2 alpha chains and 2 gamma chains (αα��).    

Iron studies in patients with thalassemia will show increased iron levels and transferrin saturation. Ferritin levels will be elevated in individuals with thalassemia major and normal/elevated in individuals with thalassemia minor. These findings manifest since the body increases gastrointestinal iron uptake in an attempt to increase hemoglobin synthesis.  




Option Analysis

✅   Serum Ferritin  HbA1  HbA2  HbF  RDW  Increased  Low  Increased  Increased  Normal :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Serum Ferritin  HbA1  HbA2  HbF  RDW  Increased  absent Increased  Increased  Normal :
Incorrect:  This set of laboratory findings can be seen in patients with B-thalassemia major. Due to the absence of B-globin synthesis, HbA1 (ααββ), composed of 2 B-globin subunits, would be absent. This deficiency causes a resultant increase in HbA2 (ααδδ), since B-globin subunits are not required for this hemoglobin variant. Additionally, patients with B-thalassemia major typically present with severe hemolytic anemia that requires transfusion early in childhood, making this diagnosis unlikely in an adult female. 
❌   Serum Ferritin  HbA1  HbA2  HbF  RDW LowNormalNormalNormalHigh:
Incorrect: This set of laboratory findings can be seen in patients with iron deficiency anemia (IDA). The low serum ferritin indicates that there is not enough iron available for heme synthesis. This patient was empirically started on iron supplements, which did not improve her condition, making IDA a less likely diagnosis. 
❌   Serum Ferritin  HbA1  HbA2  HbF  RDW NormalAbsentAbsentDecreased Normal :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory findings can be seen in newborns with hemoglobin Barts disease. In this condition, no α-globin is produced, resulting in an absence of hemoglobin variants that incorporate the α-globin subunit (such as HbA1, HbA2, and HbF). However, hemoglobin Barts disease causes an extremely severe form of anemia, and symptoms are present at birth, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this adult female. 
❌   Serum Ferritin  HbA1  HbA2  HbF  RDW  Increased  NormalNormalNormal Normal :
Incorrect: This set of laboratory findings can be seen in patients with anemia of chronic disease. This condition occurs secondary to chronic disease (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus).

questions.text:
A 16-year-old African American boy presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of weakness, shortness of breath, and fatigue. The patient denies chest pain, and his mother explains that the patient has had symptoms of “the common cold” for the past few days. Family history includes sickle cell disease. Temperature is 37°C (98.9°F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 126/76 mmHg. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and pallor. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits, and abdominal examination does not reveal hepatosplenomegaly. Chest x-ray is within normal limits. Laboratory tests are obtained, and the results are shown below.


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a family history of sickle cell disease, recent respiratory infection, and anemia has aplastic crisis secondary to parvovirus B19 infection and sickle cell disease. Sickle cell disease (SCD) is a chronic condition marked by hemolytic anemia that is typically well-compensated with appropriate reticulocytosis. Aplastic crisis typically occurs secondary to parvovirus B19 infections because of the virus’s predisposition for infecting proliferating erythroid progenitors; the condition is characterized by anemia with transient arrest of erythropoiesis and therefore decreased reticulocyte count (less than 1%).  



Other complications associated with sickle cell disease result from either intravascular hemolysis or vaso-occlusion. Intravascular hemolysis is associated with anemia, jaundice, gallstones, and extramedullary hematopoiesis. Extramedullary hematopoiesis presents with enlarged cheeks, ‘hair-on-end’ appearance on x-ray, and hepatomegaly.



Vaso-occlusion can present acutely or chronically. Acute vaso-occlusion, also called sickle cell crisis, can present in many different parts of the body and is classified accordingly. Patients typically experience excruciating pain that starts suddenly and lasts from hours to days.





Chronic complications of vaso-occlusion may include growth and developmental delay, learning and behavioral disorders, pulmonary hypertension, kidney disease, autosplenectomy, and susceptibility to encapsulated bacteria. Autosplenectomy results from vaso-occlusion and splenic infarcts. Biopsy of the spleen will reveal significant fibrosis and atrophy, and since the spleen plays an important role in immunity against encapsulated bacteria, the person will be susceptible to Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis infections.


Abdominal CT of patient with autosplenectomy

One common complication of increased susceptibility to encapsulated bacteria is osteomyelitis. The most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with SCD is Salmonella species, with Staphylococcus aureus (the most common in patients without SCD) accounts for less than 25% of cases.


Option Analysis

❌ Acute chest syndrome:
Incorrect: Acute chest syndrome is characterized by chest pain, fever, and pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray. This patient with no chest pain, a normal chest x-ray, anemia, and severe reticulocytopenia has aplastic crisis.
❌ Aplastic anemia  :
Incorrect: Aplastic anemia is characterized by fatigue, pallor, and dyspnea, which is consistent with the signs and symptoms seen in the vignette; however, the laboratory findings for aplastic anemia should show pancytopenia.
✅ Aplastic crisis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperhemolytic crisis:
Incorrect: Hyperhemolytic crisis is a rare complication of sickle cell disease and is characterized by sudden severe anemia with an appropriate reticulocyte response. This patient with a low reticulocyte count has aplastic crisis.
❌ Splenic sequestration crisis:
Incorrect: Splenic sequestration occurs secondary to vaso-occlusion of red blood cells in the spleen, leading to hypotensive shock. Physical examination would reveal splenomegaly.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinician by his parents due to easy fatigability and growth delay. They recently immigrated to the United States. The mother did not receive any prenatal care in her home country. The child was born at term by a normal vaginal delivery. He is at the 30th percentile for length and below the 10th percentile for weight. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. Hematological tests and hemoglobin electrophoresis are obtained:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin (Hb)  10.8 g/dL 
 Hematocrit (Hct)  32% 
 Erythrocyte count  5.7 million/mm3 
 Hemoglobin A2 (HbA2)   6.5% 
 Fetal hemoglobin (HbF)  60% 
 Hemoglobin A (HbA1)  None 
 Hemoglobin S (HbS)  None 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with growth delay, fatigability, and hepatosplenomegaly (indicating extramedullary hematopoiesis). He also has laboratory investigations showing a low hemoglobin and absent HbA1 on hemoglobin electrophoresis. As a result, he most likely has β-thalassemia major.  

β-thalassemia major (homozygous) occurs when both genes coding for the β-globin chains on chromosome 11 are mutated, leading to absent (or minimal) β-chain production. Microcytic anemia typically develops during the first year of life, usually after six months of age. This is because in the first six months of life, the major hemoglobin is fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which uses γ-chains instead of β-chains.  

Clinical features of β-thalassemia major include symptoms and signs of severe anemia due to ineffective erythropoiesis and extravascular hemolysis such as fatigability, failure to thrive, high-output heart failure, and pallor. There may also be jaundice and dark urine from extravascular hemolysis. Patients may have evidence of extramedullary hematopoiesis including hepatosplenomegaly and craniofacial abnormalities such as thickened facial bones (“chipmunk facies”). Skull radiographs may show a translucent medullary space with hair-like projections (“hair on end” or “crew cut” appearance).  


Hemoglobin electrophoresis for β-thalassemia major will show HbA2 > 5%, HbF up to 95%, and no HbA1. Since β-chains are absent, no HbA1 can be made. The body increases HbA2 and HbF (neither of which contain β-chains) production to compensate for the absence of normal HbA1.  



Option Analysis

❌ α-thalassemia major:
Incorrect: α-thalassemia major (also termed hemoglobin Barts disease) is a cause of severe anemia that manifests in utero. The condition is incompatible with life, and infants present with hydrops fetalis at birth. α-thalassemia major occurs when all four genes coding for the α-globin chain on chromosome 16 are mutated. As a result, there is no production of α-globin, and instead, the excess γ-globin forms γ4 hemoglobin. Electrophoresis demonstrates absent HbF, HbA, and HbA2.
❌ Hemoglobin H disease:
Incorrect: Hemoglobin H (HbH) disease is also a cause of moderate microcytic hypochromic anemia. The condition occurs when three out of four genes coding for the α-globin chain on chromosome 16 are mutated. Although the condition is compatible with life, newborns with HbH disease present with moderate hemolytic anemia and jaundice. Also, laboratory panels in HbH disease will show the presence of some HbA1. In contrast, this patient has no HbA1, making HbH disease unlikely.
❌ β-thalassemia minor :
Incorrect: β-thalassemia minor (heterozygote) is another cause of microcytic hypochromic anemia and is usually asymptomatic. It occurs when one of the β-globin chain genes is mutated, leading to β-chain underproduction. Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying HbA2 (> 3.5%) and HbF (up to 5%) on electrophoresis. This patient is symptomatic, and HbF levels are higher than expected, hence making the diagnosis of β-thalassemia minor unlikely. 
✅ β-thalassemia major:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sickle cell trait :
Incorrect: Sickle cell trait (heterozygous) occurs when a point mutation causes a single amino acid replacement in the β-chain, resulting in the production of mutated hemoglobin S (HbS). The condition is mostly asymptomatic; patients are not anemic and have a normal life expectancy. Electrophoresis is likely to show HbA1 ∼50-60%, HbA2 <3.5%, HbS ∼30%, and HbF <2%. This patient has no HbS at all, making this diagnosis very unlikely.
❌ Sickle cell disease:
Incorrect: Sickle cell disease (homozygous) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs when a point mutation causes a single amino acid replacement in the β-chain, producing mutated hemoglobin S (HbS). Low O2, high altitude, or acidosis precipitates sickling (deoxygenated HbS polymerizes), leading to vaso-occlusive disease as well as extravascular and intravascular hemolysis. Patients are asymptomatic at birth due to the presence of high HbF and low HbS. Electrophoresis is likely to show absent HbA1, HbA2 <3.5%, HbS ∼90%, and HbF ∼10%. This patient has no HbS at all, and no other features of sickle cell disease, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for a routine visit. Five months ago, his wife died from a stroke. The patient reports feeling depressed, and he has been consuming large quantities of vodka on a daily basis. He previously ate a balanced diet. However, he has had little motivation to cook since his wife passed away, and he currently eats crackers and beef jerky purchased from a convenience store. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 117/81 mmHg, pulse is 71/min, and respiratory rate is 12/min. Complete blood count reveals a hemoglobin of 9.2 g/dL and a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 110 µm3. A peripheral smear is ordered and the results are as follow:  



Reproduced from: Flickr  

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's findings?

choices.text: Iron deficiency secondary to bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract
Impaired DNA synthesis resulting from vitamin B12 deficiency
Impaired DNA synthesis resulting from vitamin B9 deficiency
Replacement of bone marrow by scar tissue

questions.solution:
This patient has macrocytic anemia secondary to vitamin B9 (folate) deficiency. Common causes include poor diet, medication side-effects, and excessive alcohol consumption. Folate is obtained by consuming leafy greens and fortified foods. It is converted to tetrahydrofolic acid (THF), which plays an important role in the synthesis of nitrogenous bases that are incorporated into DNA and RNA. As a result, folate deficiency impairs DNA synthesis and hinders the maturation of hematopoietic cell lines.  

Folate deficiency causes macrocytic anemia. This is because RBC precursors are normally big (MCV > 100 µm3) and undergo cell divisions as they mature, resulting in normal, smaller RBCs. With folate deficiency, RBC maturation is impaired. This causes megaloblasts (structurally abnormal immature RBCs) to be released into the bloodstream. The net result is macrocytic megaloblastic anemia. Likewise, folate deficiency impairs white blood cell (WBC) maturation, resulting in immature hypersegmented neutrophils (greater than 5 lobes), as seen on this patient’s peripheral smear.  

Folate deficiency causes fatigue, pallor, and glossitis. Diagnosis relies on a peripheral blood smear, which shows large red blood cells and hypersegmented neutrophils. A bone marrow study can also be done to look for the megaloblastic changes in RBC precursors. Homocysteine levels are also elevated. Of note, methylmalonic acid levels are normal in patients with folate deficiency.  


Option Analysis

❌ Iron deficiency secondary to bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract:
Incorrect: Excess alcohol consumption can cause esophageal varices, erosive gastritis, and decreased synthesis of clotting factors, all of which can lead to gastrointestinal tract bleeding. This in turn may lead to iron deficiency anemia. However, iron deficiency anemia presents with a normocytic or microcytic anemia (MCV < 80 µm3), not a macrocytic anemia.  
❌ Impaired DNA synthesis resulting from vitamin B12 deficiency:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 deficiency can impair nucleotide synthesis and cause macrocytic anemia (MCV > 100 µm3). His alcohol use puts him at increased risk of vitamin B12 deficiency. However, the body has a store of vitamin B12 that requires 3-5 years to deplete. In contrast, this patient has been consuming a nutritionally-poor diet for only five months.  
✅ Impaired DNA synthesis resulting from vitamin B9 deficiency  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Defect in homologous DNA recombination:
Incorrect: Fanconi anemia is secondary to defects in homologous DNA recombination. Patients with this condition present with pancytopenia, short stature, skeletal defects, and cafe-au-lait spots. While this patient has anemia, he has none of the other symptoms typically observed in Fanconi anemia. Moreover, patients with Fanconi anemia will present with symptoms beginning in childhood.  
❌ Replacement of bone marrow by scar tissue:
Incorrect: This describes primary myelofibrosis, a condition characterized by the uncontrolled proliferation of megakaryocytes and scar tissue deposition. Over time, the hematopoietic stem cells residing in the bone marrow are crowded out by scar tissue. This results in pancytopenia and a “dry tap” on bone marrow biopsy. However, it would be atypical for primary myelofibrosis to present with the hypersegmented neutrophil observed on peripheral blood smear.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 40 weeks gestation comes to the emergency department in labor. She states that she received minimal prenatal care. The newborn is delivered vaginally shortly after arrival, but he appears jaundiced at birth and has an APGAR score of 2 and 3 at 1 minute and 5 minutes, respectively. The newborn is immediately transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit, where immediate resuscitation is attempted. The patient’s total bilirubin is elevated and hemoglobin levels are low. Peripheral blood smear shows microspherocytes and abundant reticulocytes. The patient’s family history is non-contributory. Which of the following tests is most likely to be positive in this newborn?
questions.solution:
In this newborn with jaundice immediately after birth and severe hemolytic disease, the most likely diagnosis is Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN). Rh hemolytic disease of the newborn typically occurs in an Rh(+) fetus born to an Rh(-) mother previously exposed to Rh(+) blood through either a blood transfusion or fetomaternal hemorrhage from a previous pregnancy. During the pregnancy, preformed maternal anti-D IgG, which were produced as a result of the prior exposure, cross the placenta and opsonize fetal erythrocytes. This can be prevented with the administration of anti-D IgG (RhoGAM) to Rh(-) pregnant women during the third trimester around 28 weeks gestation and immediately postpartum, to prevent the mother’s immune system from creating the antibodies itself.  

Prenatal indirect Coombs test of the mother’s blood can aid in the diagnosis of Rh alloimmunization in the mother, and postnatal direct Coombs test of the newborn’s blood can identify hemolytic disease in the newborn.  In a direct Coombs test, Coombs reagent (anti-immunoglobulin antibody) is added to the patient’s erythrocytes. Erythrocyte agglutination is indicative of a positive test. This is used in the diagnosis of autoimmune hemolytic anemias and hemolytic disease of the newborn. In an indirect Coombs test, normal erythrocytes are added to a patient’s serum. Erythrocyte agglutination upon addition of Coombs reagent is indicative of a positive test. This is used prenatally in pregnant women to test for Rh alloimmunization and in any patient prior to a blood transfusion.  



Option Analysis

❌ Indirect Coombs test:
Incorrect: The indirect Coombs test is used prenatally to examine the mother’s blood for IgG antibodies that could potentially cause hemolytic disease in the newborn. However, the indirect Coombs test would not be positive in the newborn.   
❌ Ristocetin test:
Incorrect:  The ristocetin test is used in the diagnosis of von Willebrand’s disease, a type of intrinsic pathway coagulation defect. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with a hemolytic anemia than with a bleeding disorder.  
✅ Direct Coombs test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osmotic fragility test  :
Incorrect: The osmotic fragility test is used in the diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis. In patients with this disorder, the spherocytosis itself does not present in the immediate postnatal period on peripheral smear. The microspherocytes seen on peripheral blood smear in this case are instead related to the immune destruction of the newborn’s red blood cells.  
❌ Schilling test:
Incorrect: The Schilling test is used to determine whether a patient’s Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency is due to insufficient intake or malabsorption. The presence of the anemia associated with B12 deficiency would not account for this patient’s clinical deterioration.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of fatigue and shortness of breath for the past several weeks. He lives in a 2nd floor apartment and has difficulty catching his breath after climbing the stairs. He also reports feeling tingling in his hands and feet during this same time period. The patient recently immigrated from India and was being treated for a disease with a daily medication, but cannot recall its name. He has no cognitive impairment, abnormal bleeding episodes, or depression. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 124/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. There is diminished sensation bilaterally on the hands and feets. Laboratory investigations show a hemoglobin of 9.4 g/dL. Bone marrow biopsy reveals numerous hypochromic erythrocytes with coarse basophilic granules, which are positive for Prussian blue staining. Reduced activity of which of the following enzymes is likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has fatigue, dyspnea, and a peripheral blood smear exhibiting sideroblasts. Given the patient recently immigrated from India (a tuberculosis endemic country) and has peripheral neuropathy, he was likely taking isoniazid, which can cause pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency. As a result, the patient’s symptoms are likely due to sideroblastic anemia caused by reduced activity of δ-aminolevulinate (ALA) synthase (which uses vitamin B6 as a cofactor).  

Sideroblastic anemia is a type of anemia wherein sideroblasts, or erythrocytes with abnormal mitochondrial iron deposition that form a perinuclear ring, are found in bone marrow biopsies. Due to the elevated iron content of these cells, they appear blue with Prussian blue staining.    

Sideroblastic anemia can be congenital or acquired. An X-linked defect in the ALA synthase gene is a congenital cause. Lead exposure, myelodysplastic syndromes, alcohol use, and isoniazid treatment are acquired causes.  

Isoniazid interferes with the metabolism of pyridoxine. Therefore, patients taking this medication are at increased risk of peripheral neuropathy due to S-adenosylmethionine accumulation, as well as sideroblastic anemia, since pyridoxine is an essential coenzyme used in the rate-limiting step of heme synthesis by ALA synthase. To prevent these complications, patients being treated with isoniazid should also receive supplemental pyridoxine.    






Option Analysis

✅ δ-aminolevulinate synthase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ δ-aminolevulinate dehydratase:
Incorrect: δ-aminolevulinate (ALA) dehydratase is the second enzyme involved in heme synthesis. This enzyme can be inhibited in patients with lead poisoning. 
❌ Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase   :
Incorrect: In patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, there is impaired regeneration of reduced glutathione, which is an important antioxidant. Patients typically develop hemolytic anemia after being exposed to an oxidative stressor (e.g., infection, fava beans, certain antibiotics). Although this condition can present with anemia, it also causes jaundice and dark urine, which are absent in this patient. As a result, it is unlikely this patient has G6PD deficiency.
❌ Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase :
Incorrect: Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is an enzyme involved in metabolism of methylmalonyl-CoA and requires vitamin B12 as a cofactor. In patients with vitamin B12 deficiency, elevated methylmalonic acid can damage myelin, resulting in subacute combined degeneration, which commonly presents with peripheral neuropathy. However, vitamin B12 deficiency would not account for the sideroblasts seen on bone marrow aspiration.
❌ Porphobilinogen deaminase :
Incorrect: Porphobilinogen deaminase deficiency is seen in patients with acute intermittent porphyria (AIP). AIP typically presents as severe abdominal pain, neurologic abnormalities, and red-purple urine. Although this patient also has neurologic abnormalities (e.g. peripheral neuropathy), the presence of sideroblasts on bone marrow aspiration makes another diagnosis more likely.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy comes to the emergency department complaining of 2 days of fatigue, large purple spots on his legs, and bleeding in his mouth from the gums. He has no significant past medical history, and family history is unremarkable. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 108/66 mmHg. Upon physical exam, he is found to have pale skin, large purpura on his legs bilaterally, and bleeding mucosal petechiae. Laboratory tests are obtained and the results are shown below. Direct Coombs test is positive.    

Laboratory value  Result
 Hematologic 
 Hemoglobin  8.1 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)   86 fL 
 Platelet count  80,000/mm3  
 Reticulocyte count   4.6% 
 Haptoglobin  100 mg/dL (N = 50-220) 
Blood, plasma, serum  
 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)  1080 U/L 
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with signs and symptoms consistent with extravascular hemolytic anemia (normal haptoglobin and fatigue), thrombocytopenia (low platelet count, purpura, and mucosal petechiae), and a direct Coombs test most likely has Evan’s syndrome. Evan’s syndrome is a rare disease that is defined as a combination of immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) and autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). Immune thrombocytopenic purpura is a disorder in which autoantibodies bind to platelets and mark them for destruction in the spleen, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia is a disorder in which autoantibodies bind to erythrocytes and mark them for destruction in the spleen. Diagnosis is confirmed by laboratory findings, which would show positive direct Coombs test as well as markers of hemolysis (e.g., elevated LDH, elevated unconjugated bilirubin).  



Option Analysis

❌ Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura:
Incorrect: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is a type of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and patients present with signs and symptoms consistent with thrombocytopenia and hemolytic anemia as in this patient. However, the direct Coombs test would be negative.   
❌ Valve-associated hemolysis:
Incorrect: Valve-associated hemolytic anemia is a type of macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia most commonly associated with aortic stenosis or a prosthetic mitral valve. The patient would have signs and symptoms consistent with extrinsic hemolytic anemia, such as elevated LDH (which is seen in this patient), as well as decreased haptoglobin (which is normal in this patient), but not thrombocytopenia. The direct Coombs test would be negative.   
✅ Evan’s syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hemolytic uremic syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is a type of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, in which patients present with signs and symptoms consistent with thrombocytopenia and hemolytic anemia, as in this patient. However, the direct Coombs test would be negative, and the patient would also have renal failure.   
❌ Autoimmune hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is a type of extrinsic hemolytic anemia associated with a positive direct Coombs test but not thrombocytopenia. Therefore, this diagnosis would not explain all of the symptoms present in this patient, specifically the purpura and mucosal bleeding.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parent due to repeated episodes of jaundice, pallor, and fatigue for the last 8 months and new-onset abdominal pain for the last 3 days. She is at the 35th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. The parent reports no pregnancy or birth-related complications and states that the patient had been relatively healthy previously. The parent states that the girl’s biological father had been hospitalized with similar symptoms as a child and had abdominal surgery, but the details of the surgery are unknown. The patient’s temperature is 37°C (98.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg. Physical examination shows an ill-appearing pale child with scleral icterus and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests are obtained and the results are shown below. The patient most likely has a defect in which of the following?

Laboratory ValueResult
Hematologic
Leukocyte count6,500/mm3
Platelet count250,000/mm3
Hemoglobin9.6 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)84 fL
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)42 g/dL (normal 32-36 g/dL)
Red cell distribution width (RDW)15%
Reticulocyte count9.1%

choices.text: Single amino acid in the beta chain of hemoglobin

questions.solution:
This patient with abdominal pain, growth delay, scleral icterus, splenomegaly, anemia, and increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) has hereditary spherocytosis. Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant condition that commonly presents for the first time in children near the age of 5. It is caused by an inherited defect of the erythrocyte cytoskeleton-membrane tethering proteins: ankyrin, spectrin, or band 3. Loss of membrane integrity leads to the formation of membrane blebs, and erythrocytes assume a round shape (spherocytes). These spherocytes are unable to maneuver through splenic sinusoids and are consumed by macrophages in the spleen.

Peripheral Blood Smear Showing Spherocytes


Reproduced from:

Characteristic laboratory findings include increased RDW and MCHC. Definitive diagnosis is made via osmotic fragility test, which demonstrates spherocyte fragility in a hypotonic solution. Eosin-5-maleimide (EMA) binding is another test that can be performed. EMA is an eosin-based fluorescent dye that binds to RBC membrane proteins; since patients with HS lack these proteins, there will be decreased fluorescence of EMA-labeled RBCs in a flow cytometry-based assay. Treatment includes splenectomy (which is likely the abdominal surgery this child’s father previously had).  

Option Analysis

✅ Erythrocyte cytoskeleton-membrane tethering proteins:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ GPI anchor glycolipid:
Incorrect: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is associated with impaired synthesis of the GPI anchor glycolipids for decay-accelerating factor (DAF/CD55) and membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis (MIRL/CD59). This patient with increased MCHC has hereditary spherocytosis.
❌ Single amino acid in the beta chain of hemoglobin:
Incorrect: A single amino acid point mutation from glutamic acid to valine in the beta chain of hemoglobin  is associated with sickle cell anemia. This patient with increased MCHC has hereditary spherocytosis.
❌ Ferroportin-mediated intestinal iron transport:
Incorrect: Impaired ferroportin-mediated intestinal iron transport is associated with anemia of chronic disease. This patient with increased MCHC has hereditary spherocytosis.
❌ Glutathione-mediated protection from oxidative stress:
Incorrect: Glutathione-mediated protection from oxidative stress is impaired in glucose-6-phosphatase dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD). This patient with increased MCHC has hereditary spherocytosis.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of daily headaches and blurry vision. These symptoms started two months ago. In addition, the patient reports feeling itchy over his body after bathing or visiting the sauna. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and asymptomatic gallstones were discovered on a recent ultrasound. The patient is a former smoker with a 20-pack-year smoking history. On the physical exam, the patient is observed to have facial plethora and a spleen palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory testing is ordered and the results are as follows:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  18.1 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  54% 
 Erythrocytes  7.2 million/mm3 
 Leukocytes  12,500/mm3 
 Platelets  470,000/mm3 
 Uric Acid  7.9 mg/dL 

Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Increased erythrocyte production secondary to hypoxia
Deposition of bile acids in the skin
Autoimmune destruction of myelin in the central nervous system

questions.solution:
This patient has polycythemia vera, a myeloproliferative neoplasm most commonly caused by a Janus Kinase 2 (JAK2) gene mutation. The mutation allows myeloid cell lines, most notably erythrocytes, to proliferate in the absence of erythropoietin (EPO). Patients may also present with elevated leukocyte and platelet counts.  

Patients present with a combination of constitutional symptoms and symptoms secondary to increased blood viscosity. Constitutional symptoms include weight loss and fatigue. Hyperviscosity leads to visual changes, facial plethora, and hepatosplenomegaly. Patients will also have elevated mast cell and basophil cell counts due to leukocyte proliferation. This causes pruritus that is exacerbated by hot temperatures.  

Work-up includes getting a complete blood count (CBC), uric acid level, and EPO level. CBC will show significantly elevated RBC counts in combination with mildly elevated leukocyte and platelet counts. Uric acid levels are elevated due to increased cell turnover. EPO levels will be below the normal reference range.  

Phlebotomy is used to reduce RBC count and viscosity. Aspirin can be administered to reduce the risk of thrombosis. Cytoreduction agents such ruxolitinib (a JAK2 inhibitor) can be administered in severe cases to slow down neoplastic cell proliferation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Increased erythrocyte production secondary to hypoxia:
Incorrect: Hypoxia causes the release of erythropoietin (EPO) and results in increased red blood cell production. This may account for the patient’s elevated hemoglobin and hematocrit. However, hypoxia would not account for the elevated leukocyte and platelet count or the splenomegaly observed in this patient.
✅ Erythropoietin-independent proliferation of erythrocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased blood plasma volume:
Incorrect: This describes relative polycythemia. The condition is often secondary to dehydration or fluid loss via burns, wherein the individual’s blood plasma volume decreases dramatically while the RBC count remains roughly unchanged. The net result is hemoconcentration. However, no part of the patient’s history or physical exam suggests that he is volume depleted.  
❌ Deposition of bile acids in the skin :
Incorrect: Cholestasis can cause pruritis secondary to the accumulation and deposition of bile acids in the skin. This patient’s gallstones may obstruct the common bile duct, cause choledocolithiasis, and impede bile flow. However, patients with choledocolithiasis typically have additional symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant tenderness. The patient in this vignette has none of these symptoms.  
❌ Autoimmune destruction of myelin in the central nervous system:
Incorrect: This describes multiple sclerosis, which may cause symptoms including vision impairment, headaches, paresthesias, and impaired coordination. This patient endorses vision changes and headaches. However, multiple sclerosis typically presents between 20-40 years-old. Moreover, multiple sclerosis would not account for the patient’s elevated RBC, WBC, and platelet counts.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fatigue, jaundice, paleness, and difficulty breathing for the past week. He states that the symptoms started suddenly. He denies any recent illnesses, sick contacts, or recent travel. His past medical history is significant for hypertension, rheumatic fever, hypercholesterolemia, and mitral valve regurgitation. Past surgical history includes a mitral valve replacement 2 months ago.  Current medications include lisinopril, simvastatin, and warfarin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 108/66 mmHg. Physical examination shows pallor. Laboratory test findings are shown below:  

 
Laboratory value  Results 
 Hematologic  
 Leukocyte count   9,600/mm3 
 Erythrocyte count   3.2 million/mm3 
 Platelet count  260,000/mm3  
 Hematocrit  31% 
 Hemoglobin  9.4 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)   88 fL 
 Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)  34% Hb/cell 
 Reticulocyte count   4.2% 
Blood, plasma, serum  
 Haptoglobin  Undetectable 
 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)  380 U/L 
 Total bilirubin  5 mg/dL 
 Direct bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s anemia?
questions.solution:
This patient with signs and symptoms of hemolytic anemia (hemoglobinemia, jaundice, pallor, fatigue, shortness of breath) along with recent surgical history of prosthetic mitral valve replacement has intravascular macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia caused by mechanical destruction of erythrocytes.  

Extrinsic hemolytic anemia can be differentiated according to the location of the red blood cell destruction by categorizing into intravascular and extravascular hemolysis. Extravascular hemolysis is defined by red blood cell destruction outside of blood vessels, typically in the reticuloendothelial system. Intravascular hemolysis is defined by red blood cell destruction within blood vessels. Intravascular hemolytic anemia can be further characterized based on the size of the blood vessel, categorized into microangiopathic and macroangiopathic hemolysis. In this patient, his microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is likely the result of his recent mitral valve prostheses causing destruction of his erythrocytes.  

  •  Macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia results in erythrocyte destruction in the systemic circulation due to mechanical forces applied to the erythrocyte membrane. This can be seen in conditions such as moderate and severe aortic stenosis, prosthetic heart valves, and strenuous exercise. 
  •  Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia results in erythrocyte destruction in the systemic circulation due to microthrombi in small blood vessels. This can be seen in conditions such as thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).  
These 2 types of hemolytic anemias are difficult to distinguish based on laboratory findings alone, since the hemolysis results in similar findings (e.g., schistocytes on blood smear, decreased haptoglobin, elevated LDH). However, the clinical scenario can help clarify which hemolytic process is occurring; in patients with chronic anemic signs and aortic stenosis or prosthetic valves, macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia should be suspected. In contrast, in patients with acute anemia and presenting as severely ill (e.g., TTP, HUS, DIC), microangiopathic hemolytic anemia should be suspected.  
 

Option Analysis

❌ Extravascular hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Extravascular hemolytic anemia includes autoimmune hemolytic anemia, drug-induced hemolytic anemia, infectious hemolytic anemia, and inherited intrinsic hemolytic anemias. Erythrocytes are typically marked by antibodies for destruction in the reticuloendothelial system. In contrast, this patient likely has an intravascular hemolytic anemia, which can be inferred by his undetectable haptoglobin levels and recent valve replacement, making him at increased risk of macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia.  
❌ Drug-induced hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Drug-induced hemolytic anemia is a type of immune-mediated hemolytic anemia that can be either intravascular or extravascular. Some common drugs associated with this type of hemolytic anemia include penicillins, cephalosporins, alpha-methyldopa, L-dopa, ibuprofen, diclofenac, quinidine, hydrochlorothiazide, sulfonamides, and tetracyclines. This patient is not currently taking any medications that would predispose him to drug-induced hemolysis.  
❌ Intravascular microangiopathic hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Intravascular microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), HELLP syndrome, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). These various causes of microangiopathic hemolytic anemias typically present acutely, with patient’s appearing severely ill within hours to days. In contrast, this patient’s 1-week history of fatigue, in conjunction with his recent valve replacement, likely suggest a macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia.   
❌ Autoimmune hemolytic anemia:
Incorrect: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) is a type of antibody-mediated hemolytic anemia that can be due to warm antibodies (IgG) or cold antibodies (IgM). Warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia is an extravascular hemolytic process (i.e. takes place in the spleen), whereas cold autoimmune hemolytic anemia can be either an intravascular or extravascular process. This patient likely has an intravascular hemolytic anemia, which can be inferred by his undetectable haptoglobin levels; in conjunction with his recent valve replacement, this likely suggests a macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia.  
✅ Intravascular macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the primary care office because of a three-month history of progressive fatigue, abdominal pain, and darker-than-normal urine, especially in the morning. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg. Physical examination is within normal limits. Laboratory tests are obtained, and the results are shown below.


Sucrose hemolysis test is positive. The patient's condition is most likely attributed to which of the following?

choices.text: Intrinsic hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis
Extrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis
Intrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis
Extrinsic hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis
Positive direct Coombs test with extravascular hemolysis

questions.solution:
This patient with dark urine in the morning, normocytic anemia, decreased haptoglobin, pancytopenia, and positive sucrose hemolysis test has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). PNH is an intrinsic, intravascular hemolytic anemia. Extrinsic anemia is defined as hemolysis resulting from a problem outside of the erythrocyte and is typically acquired (e.g., autoimmune, infections, microangiopathic), whereas intrinsic anemia is defined as hemolysis resulting from a problem with the erythrocyte itself and is typically caused by enzyme deficiencies, commonly seen in congenital conditions (e.g., PNH, sickle cell disease, G6PD, hereditary spherocytosis).  

The type of hemolysis can be determined based on symptoms and laboratory findings. In intravascular hemolysis, hemoglobin that is released inside vessels gets bound by haptoglobin, and both molecules are removed together. Therefore, haptoglobin levels decrease. Once the haptoglobin gets overwhelmed, the remainder of the hemoglobin travels via the blood to the kidneys. Here, it is excreted in the urine and causes hemoglobinuria. While passing through the renal tubules, some of the hemoglobin is reabsorbed by the cells lining the tubule. The iron component of the heme is stored in these cells as hemosiderin for a few days. Eventually, these cells slough into the urine and cause hemosiderinuria.  


In extravascular hemolysis, erythrocytes are destroyed outside of the blood vessels, typically in the liver or spleen. Therefore, patients may present with splenomegaly or hepatomegaly. However, haptoglobin levels are normal, and there is no hemoglobinuria or hemosiderinuria.

Option Analysis

❌ Intrinsic hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis:
Incorrect: This patient has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), a type of intrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis. Extravascular hemolysis would not cause decreased haptoglobin levels.
❌ Extrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis:
Incorrect: This patient has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), a type of intrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis. Extrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis is unlikely to cause pancytopenia.
✅ Intrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Extrinsic hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis:
Incorrect: This patient has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), a type of intrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis. Extrinsic hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis would not cause pancytopenia, decreased haptoglobin, or positive sucrose test.
❌ Positive direct Coombs test with extravascular hemolysis:
Incorrect: This patient has paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH), a type of intrinsic hemolytic anemia with intravascular hemolysis. A direct Coombs test is used to detect autoimmune or drug-induced hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the clinic with low-grade fevers, fatigue, paleness, shortness of breath, and a nonproductive cough for the past 2 weeks. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg. Chest auscultation reveals mild wheezing and crackles bilaterally. Chest X-ray shows bilateral patchy infiltrates. Direct Coombs test is positive. Which of the following classes of antibodies is most likely implicated in this disease process?
questions.solution:
This patient with 2 weeks of low-grade fevers, shortness of breath, and nonproductive cough likely has a form of atypical “walking” pneumonia. Given the positive Coombs test, the most likely cause of pneumonia is Mycoplasma pneumoniae, which can cause a cold (IgM-mediated) autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). This occurs as a result of the production of cold agglutinins, which are autoantibodies that target erythrocyte membranes, resulting in clumping of erythrocytes. This may be visualized on peripheral blood smear, and diagnosis is confirmed by a positive direct Coombs test.  

There are two types of AIHA: cold (IgM-mediated) and warm (IgG-mediated). Cold AIHA is mediated by cold agglutinins and warm AIHA is mediated by warm agglutinins. Cold agglutinins bind erythrocytes in areas of the body at lower temperatures, and warm agglutinins bind erythrocytes in areas of the body at higher temperatures. Both are associated with extravascular hemolysis. Common causes of IgG-mediated AIHA include chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Non-hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL), and other non-lymphoid malignancies. Common causes of IgM-mediated AIHA include Mycoplasma pneumoniae, mononucleosis, and Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia.  



Option Analysis

❌ Immunoglobulin A (IgA):
Incorrect: Immunoglobulin A (IgA) acts by inhibiting infectious organisms from attaching to the mucous membranes. It primarily protects against gastrointestinal infections such as Giardia.   
✅ Immunoglobulin M (IgM)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Immunoglobulin G (IgG):
Incorrect: Immunoglobulin G (IgG) is associated with warm autoimmune hemolytic anemia, which is commonly due to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), and some drugs such as alpha-methyldopa.  
❌ Immunoglobulin E (IgE):
Incorrect: Immunoglobulin E (IgE) is associated with type I hypersensitivity (HS) reactions and activates eosinophils in response to parasitic infections.   
❌ Immunoglobulin D (IgD):
Incorrect: Immunoglobulin D (IgD) is found on B cells and in the blood, but its function is unclear.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinician by his parents due to easy fatigability and growth delay. They recently immigrated to the United States. The mother did not receive any prenatal care in her home country. The child was born at term by a normal vaginal delivery. He is at the 30th percentile for length and below the 10th percentile for weight. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory testing is obtained and the patient is diagnosed with β-thalassemia major. The patient is given the appropriate treatment and his condition dramatically improves. Which of the following is a likely long-term complication resulting from this treatment?
questions.solution:
The patient was recently diagnosed with β-thalassemia major and now requires chronic blood transfusions in order to prevent complications and increase survival. Transfusions are a necessity for this condition; however, without the appropriate supportive treatment, iron overload from these transfusions can lead to secondary hemochromatosis.   

Hemochromatosis can either be caused by a hereditary autosomal recessive C282Y or H63D mutation on the HFE gene (chromosome 6) or due to chronic blood transfusions. Iron overload results in iron deposition within various organs, leading to cellular damage via the formation of oxygen free radicals. The classic triad of cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, and skin pigmentation in hemochromatosis is often called "bronze diabetes." Iron deposition in the pituitary gland can cause secondary hypogonadism or hypothyroidism. Hypogonadism in men presents with low testosterone and libido, and in women with amenorrhea. The hypogonadism can eventually lead to decreased bone density.  



Option Analysis

❌ Chronic pancreatitis  :
Incorrect: Chronic pancreatitis can be caused by chronic alcohol use. Iron overload, as seen in patients with excessive transfusions due to β-thalassemia major, can damage the pancreas and lead to type 2 diabetes mellitus. However, the condition seems to selectively damage the beta cells responsible for insulin and spares other parts of the pancreas.
❌ Parkinsonism:
Incorrect: Parkinsonism and extrapyramidal symptoms can be seen with Wilson disease, a condition characterized by copper overload due to a genetic defect leading to reduced copper excretion. In contrast, this patient is at risk of iron overload due to the frequent blood transfusions needed to manage his β-thalassemia major. Iron overload can cause generalized cognitive impairment from deposition in the central nervous system, but not specifically Parkinsonism.
❌ Pigment gallstones:
Incorrect: Bilirubin (pigment) gallstones and biliary tract inflammation in beta-thalassemia patients arise secondary to high red blood cell turnover and hemolytic anemia. However, pigmented gallstones are not directly caused by chronic blood transfusions.
✅ Hypogonadism:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Skeletal changes:
Incorrect: Skeletal changes are commonly seen in severe forms of thalassemia (e.g., thalassemia major, many cases of thalassemia intermedia). It is caused secondary to ineffective erythropoiesis, which induces extramedullary hematopoiesis.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old gravida 1 para 0 woman comes to the office at 18-weeks gestation because of a week-long history of headaches, muscle pain, and recurrent fever spikes every two days. He returned from a 3-week-long trip to the Dominican Republic two weeks ago. Temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus. The spleen is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. Hemoglobin concentration is 10 g/dL. A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown below. Which of the following agents should be avoided in treating this patient’s condition?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient recently returned from a trip to a malaria-endemic region. The presence of tertian fever and trophozoite rings in erythrocytes suggest infection by Plasmodium vivax or Plasmodium ovale, both of which are treated with a combination of chloroquine and primaquine.

Primaquine is usually well tolerated but may cause gastrointestinal distress, pruritus, headaches, and methemoglobinemia. It can cause hemolytic anemia in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate-dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Thus, it is contraindicated in pregnancy since the G6PD status of the fetus is uncertain.

Therefore, pregnant women are often treated with chloroquine monotherapy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Mefloquine:
Incorrect: Mefloquine is associated with several side effects, including gastrointestinal distress, cardiac conduction defects, and neuropsychiatric complications (e.g., seizures, psychosis, depression). However, it is not contraindicated in pregnancy.  
❌ Chloroquine:
Incorrect: Chloroquine is well tolerated and is not known to have harmful effects in pregnancy.  
❌ Quinine:
Incorrect: Quinine is safe and effective and should be used when needed. However, glucose levels should be monitored, as the drug can cause maternal and fetal hypoglycemia.  
❌ Clindamycin:
Incorrect: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends treating uncomplicated Plasmodium falciparum malaria during the first trimester of pregnancy with quinine plus clindamycin for seven days.  
✅ Primaquine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician due to fatigue and low energy for the past two months. The patient tells the physician she can barely perform her daily activities and her work performance has declined. In addition, the patient reports that when she goes to the bathroom early in the morning, her urine is red in color. Last year she was diagnosed with Budd-Chiari syndrome and was prescribed anticoagulants. The patient’s labs show pancytopenia. Early morning urinalysis is positive for blood, but microscopy reveals no blood. Flow cytometry was performed and it showed decreased CD55 and CD59. The physician decides to start the patient on eculizumab. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: It binds to and blocks the activation of C5 complement protein
It binds soluble tumor necrosis factor (TNF) and prevents the activation of its receptor
It Inhibits the interaction of interleukin-17A with its receptor
It binds to integrins in blood vessel walls and prevents leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation.

questions.solution:
This patient has anemia, venous thrombosis (e.g. Budd-Chiari syndrome), and pancytopenia. In addition, flow cytometry reveals decreased expression of CD55 and CD59, indicating paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

PNH is a rare hematopoietic stem cell disorder that manifests with hemolytic anemia, bone marrow failure, and thrombosis. Hemolysis in PNH is directly mediated by the complement system and is due to a mutation in the PIGA gene that results in the absence of GPI anchor expression erythrocytes. Deficiency of GPI on erythrocytes results in the inability of complement inhibitors CD55 and CD59 to function properly. Since CD55 and CD59 protect RBCs from complement damage, their absence results in excessive hemolysis of RBCs by the complement system.

Eculizumab is the first-line treatment for PNH. It is a human monoclonal antibody that binds to and blocks the activation of C5, thereby inhibiting the formation of membrane attack complexes (MAC). By doing so, eculizumab compensates for the absence of complement inhibitors (e.g. CD59) on the erythrocytes and therefore protects them from intravascular hemolysis by MAC.

The use of eculizumab in patients with PNH has been shown to improve anemia, inhibit intravascular hemolysis and decrease the need for transfusions; reduce the risk of venous thrombosis, and improve overall quality of life.  

Option Analysis

✅ It binds to and blocks the activation of C5 complement protein:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It binds soluble tumor necrosis factor (TNF) and prevents the activation of its receptor:
Incorrect: Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody against TNF and is used in inflammatory disorders like rheumatoid arthritis. It has no role in the management of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.  
❌ It Inhibits the interaction of interleukin-17A with its receptor:
Incorrect: IL-17A inhibitors are medications that can be used in the management of severe psoriasis.  
❌ It binds to integrins in blood vessel walls and prevents leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation.:
Incorrect: Natalizumab binds to integrins on the endothelial cells of blood vessels, thereby inhibiting leukocytes from migrating to the site of inflammation. It is a drug used to treat Multiple Sclerosis.  
❌ It inhibits interleukin 12/23:
Incorrect: Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits interleukin-12/23. It can be used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents to the office because of a week of intermittent high fevers, chills, and sweats. The patient recently returned to the United States after visiting his relatives in Ghana. Past medical history is unremarkable, and he does not take any medications. Temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus. The spleen is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. Hemoglobin concentration is 10 g/dL. A peripheral blood smear is shown below. After further evaluation, the patient is started on an antiparasitic drug that is metabolized in the food vacuoles of the parasite to form toxic free radicals. Which medication was this patient most likely prescribed?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with high fevers, chills, anemia, and splenomegaly after visiting Ghana (where malaria is endemic). Peripheral blood smear reveals banana-shaped organisms. These findings suggest infection by Plasmodium falciparum, and he is started on artemisinin.

Artemisinin derivatives are a new class of antimalarials that include artemisinin, artesunate, and dihydroartemisinin. These medications are blood schizonticides that build up in the food vacuoles of the Plasmodium, where they bind to iron found in heme and generate free radicals that damage parasite proteins. Artemisinins are especially useful since they are effective against all Plasmodium species, including the strains resistant to chloroquine and other quinoline derivatives. Their effectiveness is so high that they are considered the first-choice agent for treating chloroquine-resistant malaria. However, they are not effective for prophylaxis since they have only a few hours short half-life.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Chloroquine:
Incorrect: Chloroquine accumulates in the food vacuoles of Plasmodium and prevents the polymerization of heme, a hemoglobin breakdown product, into hemozoin. Intracellular accumulation of heme is toxic to the parasite. However, chloroquine does not lead to the formation of toxic free radicals.  
❌ Proguanil:
Incorrect: Proguanil is bioactivated to cycloguanil, a selective inhibitor of protozoan dihydrofolate reductase. It does not lead to the formation of toxic free radicals.  
❌ Quinine:
Incorrect: Quinine complexes with double-stranded DNA prevent strand separation, which blocks DNA replication and RNA transcription. It is not involved in the formation of toxic free radicals.  
✅ Artemisinin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Primaquine:
Incorrect: Primaquine forms quinoline-quinone metabolites, electron-transferring redox compounds that act as cellular oxidants. The drug is a tissue schizonticide and limits malaria transmission by acting as a gametocide.
